sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
Adequate bone regeneration has been difficult to achieve at segmental bone defects
caused by disease. The surface structure and phase composition of calcium phosphate
bioceramic are crucial for its bioactivity and osteoinductivity. In the present study,
biphasic calcium phosphate (BCP) bioceramics composed of micro-whiskers and
nanoparticles hybrid-structured surface (hBCP) were fabricated via a hydrothermal
reaction. The in vivo long bone defect model of beagle dogs implanted with hBCP
bioceramics achieved a higher quality regenerated bone as compared to the traditional
smooth-surface BCP control group. After a 12-week implantation period, more new
bone formation within the implanted material and a higher fracture load were
observed in the hBCP group (p<0.05 vs. control). In addition, the local bone
integration efficacy, as determined by nanoindentation, showed a significantly closer
elastic modulus of the implanted hBCP bioceramics to that of the natural bone
adjacent. Finally, in vitro gene microarray analysis of the mesenchymal stem cells
(MSCs) co-cultured with two bioceramics showed that the hBCP group induced a
drastic downregulation of the genes associated with inflammatory response, which
was never documented in previous studies regarding biomaterials with a micro/nano
hybrid structure. The tumor necrosis factor (TNF) signalling pathway was the most
involved and preferentially inhibited by the hBCP material. Collectively, the findings
suggested that the micro/nano hybrid-structured bioceramics augmented local bone
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
regeneration at segmental bone defects and presented a potential alternative to
autologous bone grafts.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The clinical treatment of massive bone defects due to traumatic injuries or tumor
resection is still a great challenge. Pursuing alternatives to autologous bone grafts has
always been a goal of biomaterial engineering. An ideal bone substitute material may
serve as a substrate for the migration, proliferation and differentiation of cells
infiltrating from surrounding tissues, followed by bone tissue ingrowth [1]. Calcium
phosphate (CaP) ceramics with good biocompatibility, osteoconductivity and
osteoinductivity has become one of the most considered bone graft materials [2–4].
More importantly, with its osteoinductive ability, the porous CaP bioceramics was
able to achieve better regeneration even in large bone defects, without the addition of
exogenous growth factors [5,6,7]. So far, the most clinically applied CaP bone graft
materials are mainly hydroxyapatite (HA), beta-tricalcium phosphate (β-TCP), and
biphasic calcium phosphate (BCP, a combination of HA and β-TCP), in the form of
ceramics or incorporated with polymers [8,9]. Among these materials, the good
osteoinduction ability and proper degradation rate of the BCP ceramics have revealed
great potential in large bone defects repair [3,10–12].
Natural bone tissues have hierarchical structures assembled in a highly organized way
composed of nano-, micro-, and macro-scale building blocks. It has been widely
reported that surface modification with micro/nano hybrid topography on implant
materials bear a closer resemblance to the features of natural bone and therefore a
more advantageous control of biological responses and consequent in vivo bone
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
regeneration [1,13–16]. Furthermore, the hierarchical hybrid structure possess a
higher specific surface area, which will provide much more adsorption sites to the
bioactive molecules [17–19]. Generally, two types of micro/nano hybrid-structured
bone grafts were presented in literature. The first kind is a heterogeneous system often
composed of micro-structured scaffolds and CaP nanoparticles/rods on site, i.e., HA
nanoparticles-reinforced micro-fiber scaffolds made of silk [20], polycaprolactone
[21,22], chitosan [23,24] or collagen [25]. The second kind is a homogenous system
made of one material with a general structure but organized on multiple length scales.
For example, bone grafts of micro/nano mixed titania nanotubes were reported to
positively affect osteoblast differentiation and osteogenesis [13,18,26]. These studies
indicated that an enhanced defect healing can be achieved through tailoring the
surface structure of bone grafts into a multi-scale organization [8,17,26–28].
Although many studies have demonstrated the important role of the surface structure
of polymers and metals in bone regeneration, only limited studies on the controllable
fabrication of CaP bioceramics with micro/nano hybrid structure have been reported
so far. It is still a technical challenge to modify the surface of 3D macroporous
bioceramics because of their brittleness. Furthermore, most of the methods being used
in the modification of polymers and metals can only alter the outer surfaces of the
implants, and it is difficult to control the surface structure on the internal walls of the
CaP bioceramics. In recent years, researches from Jiang Chang’s group had revealed
the possibility of designing a multi-scale structured HA and calcium silicate
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
bioceramics [1,17,29,30]. The hybrid of microrods and nanorods was fabricated via a
subtle hydrothermal reaction. The effectiveness of this method was also proven in
previous studies from our group [2,31,32]. A promoted osteogenic differentiation of
human periodontal ligament stem cell was observed with micro/nano
hybrid-structured HA. However, HA bioceramics is still considered to be weak in
osteoinductive ability compared to β-TCP and BCP, which may limit its repair
capacity [33–35].
The aim of this study was to fabricate a micro/nano hybrid-structured BCP
bioceramics for segmental bone defect regeneration. The material was designed to be
composed of a micro-whiskered scaffold reinforced with nanoparticles. Rat calvarial
bone defect, femoral plug defect or intramuscular ectopic implantation models were
often used in previous studies to characterize the bone repair ability of the
bioceramics. However, there are discrepancies between rodents and human cortical
bone, i.e., the absence of Harversian remodelling in rats, calling into question the
clinical relevance. Therefore, in the current study, the bone regeneration ability of the
fabricated BCP bioceramics was assessed using a long bone defect model in beagle
dogs. During the implantation, autologous bone marrow was collected and
supplemented onto the surface of bioceramic implant so as to speed the healing
process like in clinical practice. Bone marrow contains mainly hematopoietic and
mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) which retains multipotent differentiation capacity
[36,37]. Thus, in our in vitro experiments, the cell proliferation assay and gene
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
expression profile analysis were conducted using MSCs co-cultured with bioceramics
to screen out the most relevant biological responses aroused by the micro/nano hybrid
structure.

sections.heading: 2.1. Fabrication and characterization of the hBCP bioceramics
sections.text:
The final conformation of the micro/nano hybrid-structured hBCP bioceramics
comprised the porous micro-whisker scaffold and nanoparticles (Fig. 1). First, the
BCP nanoparticle slurry and BCP powders were synthesized by a traditional chemical
precipitation method. Stirring at room temperature, 5 L of 0.85 mol/L Ca(NO3)2
solution (Sigma-Aldrich, China) was added dropwise slowly into an equal volume of
0.55 mol/L (NH4)2HPO4 solution (Chengdu Kelong Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd,
China). The pH was adjusted to 8 by adding ammonium hydroxide throughout the
mixing process. The solution was then stirred continuously for 4 hours and aged for
24 hours, followed by washing 3 times with distilled water. At this time point, the
slurry was composed of dispersive BCP nanoparticles as reported previously [38].
Thirty weight percent of the slurry was saved for the subsequent infusion procedure.
The majority of the slurry was dried at 120 °C for 24 hours and crushed to BCP
powder with a particle size of approximately 20 µm. The porous BCP ceramic
scaffolds were then fabricated using the H2O2 foaming method and sintered at
1100 °C for 2 hours. The average porosity of the BCP ceramic was about 75% and the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
macro-pore size was approximately 400 µm as characterized by mercury intrusion
method. Second, the backbone of the scaffold was then modified via hydrothermal
treatment of the as prepared BCP ceramics under 180 °C for 12 hours in an aqueous
system containing 1 mol/L nitric acid in deionized water vehicle (pH = 4.0). As
reported previously, the epitaxial growth of the micro-whiskers was achieved [31].
After hydrothermal treatment, the scaffolds were washed by soaking in distilled water
3 times and dried at 60 °C for 24 hours. Finally, the prepared BCP nanoparticle slurry
with a 30 mg/ml concentration was adsorbed into the scaffolds by vacuum infusion,
dried, and then sintered at 1100 °C. The above infusion step was repeated again with a
half-reduced slurry concentration and then sintered at 1000 °C. The micro/nano
hybrid-structured BCP bioceramic used in the current study were thus obtained.
Besides, the traditional smooth-surface porous BCP ceramics with an identical phase
composition as hBCP were fabricated as the control. The morphology and phase
composition of the bioceramics were investigated by scanning electron microscopy
(SEM, FE-SEM, Hitachi S4800, Japan) and X-ray diffraction (XRD, model X’Pert
Pro Alpha-1 PANalytical, Netherlands). The bulk ceramics were shaped into discs (Ф
13×2 mm) for cell culture and cylinders (Ф 8×12 mm) with a drilled hole in the
middle (Ф 1.5×12 mm) for implantation. Before the biological experiments, all the
ceramic materials were sterilized by γ-ray irradiation at a dose of 25 kGy.
2.2. Animal experiments
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
All procedures in the experiment were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and
Use Committee (IACUC) of Sichuan University. A total of twelve adult male beagle
dogs (9.6 ± 0.8 kg, 10-month-old) were used for the orthotopic implantation and were
randomly assigned to the hBCP or the control BCP group (n= 6 per group). The dogs
were housed in indoor cages. Food and water were supplied ad libitum. The surgical
operation was performed under general anesthesia by abdominal injection of sodium
pentobarbital (30 mg/kg body weight). An outer thigh lateral approach was performed.
The animal was placed in a supine position and its left hind leg was shaved from
ankle to hip and swabbed alternately with chlorhexidine and alcohol. The skin from
hip to knee was incised and the deep fascia was divided. By blunt dissection of the
interval of the quadriceps muscles, the femur was exposed. The periosteum was
stripped carefully by periosteal elevator so as to avoid injuring the lower extremity
parietal pleura. To stabilize the segmental defect, a double pre-bent stainless-steel
plate set was first fixed by 4 screws at the mid-shaft femur where a 12 mm long
segmental defect was then created by fretsaw. The implant was tightly fitted into the
created critical size bone defect [39]. Autologous bone marrow was aspirated from the
dissected bone using a needle and then applied onto the implant surface. The wound
was irrigated, and the muscle and skin were closed in layers. Following the surgeries,
buprenorphine (0.1 mg/animal) was intramuscularly injected to the dogs for 2 days to
relieve pain, while penicillin (40 mg/kg) was intramuscularly injected for 3 days to
prevent infections. After the operation, the animals were allowed for full
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
weight-bearing activities and received a normal diet. Conventional X-rays images
were obtained at weeks 4 and 12 (630 mA X-ray, Shimadzu, Japan). The implants
were harvested 12 weeks after implantation.

sections.heading: 2.3. Micro-computed tomography (micro-CT) analysis
sections.text:
A micro-CT imaging system (µCT 80, Scanco Medical AG, Bassersdorf, Switzerland)
was used to evaluate new bone formation within the harvested implants. All dissected
femur samples were placed in a custom-made holder to ensure that the long axis of
the femur was oriented perpendicular to the axis of the X-ray beam. The resultant
greyscale images had an isotropic voxel size of 25 µm from cone-beam reconstruction
(70 kV, 114 µA, 700 ms integration time). The obtained radiographic images were
reconstructed and analysed using Scanco software, by applying a global threshold to
segment the new bone formed from each non-degraded implant material (n=3) [40].
After thresholding, the percentage of bone formed within the implant was determined
by normalizing the calculated bone volume to the volume of the remaining bioceramic
material [3, 37–41]. All the micro-CT scanning and analysis were collected by an
expert (see the acknowledgement) who was blind to material groups.

sections.heading: 2.4. Histological observations
sections.text:
After micro-CT analysis, half of the samples were dehydrated in ascending
concentrations of alcohols from 75% to 100% and then embedded in
polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA). Longitudinal sections of each specimen were cut
to 150 µm thick by using a microtome (Leica) and were subsequently ground and
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
polished to a final thickness of about 40 µm (n=3). Then, the sections were stained
with Toluidine blue (TB) and hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) for histological
observation by a light microscope (Olympus Bx60) equipped with a digital CCD
camera. For quantification of bone to material ratio, three randomized
non-overlapping areas were analyzed per specimen using IPP 6.0 software. All data
were collected by a single observer who was blind to grouping of the samples. The
data were averaged for each individual specimen and then for each group.

sections.heading: 2.5. Macro-mechanical test
sections.text:
Another half of the harvested femur bones with implants were subjected to
compressive mechanical test with right intact femur serving as a control (n=3). Before
the mechanical test, the plate and screw were removed with care. The compressive
strength was measured by applying a vertical load to the implanted femur along the
axis using a testing machine (Instron 5848, Norwood, MA, USA). Briefly, the 15%
proximal and distal ends of the femurs were fixed with epoxy resin to maintain a
vertical position. A vertical load from an aluminum flat head was directed parallel to
the axis of the femoral diaphysis and moved at a constant displacement speed of 1
mm/min until fractured. Load-deformation curves were recorded continuously. The
maximum load and stiffness were obtained from the curve [42,44–46].

sections.heading: 2.6. Nanoindentation test
sections.text:
The remaining bulk bone-implant sample embedded in PMMA after the cutting
procedure described in section 2.4 were used for the nanoindentation test. Silicon
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
carbide paper of grit sizes 320, 500, 1200, and 4000 was consequently used to grind
the sample surface. Further polishing was done by microcloths with alumina powder
of grit sizes 3 µm and 1 µm. Immediately after 16-hour rehydration with 0.9% saline,
the samples were subjected to nanoindentation tests using G200 Nanoindenter
(Agilent Technologies Inc., Chandler, AZ) at room temperature. A Berkovich
diamond tip was used for all measurements. Based on optical microscopic
visualization, indentations were positioned in the middle of the implanted hBCP and
the control BCP material body, avoiding probing onto the new bone formed inside of
the pores. Ten indents were placed on each sample (n=3) and on neighboring natural
trabecular bone below the distal end of the implant as a reference. In this study, a
continuous stiffness measurement (CSM) was conducted to obtain the elastic modulus
(E) and hardness (H) of the samples. The detailed testing protocol was described in
our previous work [41,47].

sections.heading: 2.7. Serum protein adsorption and cell proliferation on bioceramics
sections.text:
Protein adsorption experiment was carried out in 24-well plate using the as prepared
bioceramic discs (Ф 13×2 mm). Samples were equilibrated with 0.9 ml of PBS for 1 h
at 37 °C, then 1 ml fetal bovine serum was added to each well. After incubation at
37 °C for 2 h with continuous shaking, the discs were washed three times with
deionized water for removing loose-binding proteins. After washing, 1 mL of 2%
(w/v) sodium dodecyl sulphate (SDS) solution were added to each well to desorb the
proteins attached to the surface for 2 hours. The supernatant solutions were collected
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
for protein quantitative analysis by BCA method (BCATM Protein Assay Kit, Pierce)
[48,49]. The amount of the adsorbed protein was further normalized to the specific
surface area, measured by Gemini VII 2390 Surface Area Analyzer (Micromeritics
Instrument Corp, GA, USA). All experiments were carried out in triplicate.
Mouse bone marrow-derived MSCs (Cyagen Biosciences, Guangzhou, China) were
seeded on the hBCP and the control bioceramic discs in 24-well plates at a density of
5×104 cell per/well. The cells were cultured with α-minimum essential medium
(α-MEM, Hyclone, USA) containing 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, Gibco, USA) and
1% antibiotics (penicillin/streptomycin) under 5% CO2 atmosphere at 37 °C. After
culturing for 1, 3 and 7 days, the viability of the MSCs cultured on each group was
tested by staining with fluorescein diacetate (FDA) and propidium iodide (PI, Topbio
Science, China). The staining was examined under confocal laser scanning
microscopy (CLSM, TCS SP5, Leica, Germany). Live cells were stained in green by
FDA, and dead cells were stained in red by PI. The proliferation of MSCs was further
quantified by using cell counting kit-8 (CCK-8, Dojindo, Japan) at each time point.

sections.heading: 2.8. Gene expression profile microarray
sections.text:
For microarray analysis, MSCs were seeded onto the bioceramics at a density of
2×105 cell per/well. After 48 hours, total RNA of the cells grown on ceramics was
extracted using RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen, Germany). Briefly, the samples were
washed with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) and dried with filter paper. A 700 µl
Buffer RLT volume was added to each sample to lyse the cells, and the total RNA
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
was extracted and purified following the manufacturer’s protocol. RNA quantity and
quality were measured by NanoDrop ND-1000 spectrophotometer (NanoDrop
Technology, Rockland, DE) and agarose gel electrophoresis. Agilent Mouse Whole
Genome Oligo Microarrays containing 43,000 genes were used to detect the gene
expression profiles of MSCs in each sample (KangChen Bio-tech Company, Shanghai,
China). The data were compared using bioinformatic tools and only genes with a fold
change ≥2 (up or downregulation) and p-value < 0.05 were considered. A pathway
analysis was also performed as a functional analysis mapping genes to KEGG
pathways.

sections.heading: 2.9. Quantitative reverse transcription-PCR (qRT-PCR) verification
sections.text:
To confirm the results of gene profiling analysis, certain genes of interest, including
interleukin-6 (IL-6), matrix metalloprotease-3 (MMP-3), sodium-dependent
phosphate transporter 1 (SLC20a1), plasma membrane calcium-transporting ATPase
2 (ATP2B2), fibroblast growth factor (FGF23) and insulin-like growth factor-binding
protein 5 (IGFBP5) were evaluated by qRT-PCR. The same batch of purified total
RNA samples sent for microarray analysis was used for mRNA verification. The total
RNA of the hBCP group and the control were then reversely transcribed into
complementary DNA (cDNA) using iScript cDNA Synthesis Kit (Bio-RAD, USA).
The qRT-PCR reactions were performed using SsoFast TM EvaGreen Supermix
(Bio-Rad, USA), in a CFX96TM real-time thermos cycler (Bio-Rad, USA) as
described in our previous work [11,50]. The reactions were performed in triplicate.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) was used as the housekeeping
gene to normalize the results.

sections.heading: 2.10. Statistics and data analysis
sections.text:
A statistical analysis was carried out using the SPSS v16 software and the results are
reported as mean ± SD (standard deviation). One-way ANOVA followed by
Bonferroni tests or paired t tests were performed to determine significant difference
between groups. Statistical significance was assumed at p < 0.05.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of micro/nano hybrid-structured BCP bioceramics
sections.text:
The surface morphological change of the fabricated hBCP throughout the three main
steps were demonstrated in Fig. 1. The high-magnification image indicated that the
initial porous BCP ceramic surface was composed of smooth calcium phosphate
grains. After hydrothermal treatment, a layer of 3D micro-whiskers aligned on the
backbone of the scaffold. These micro-whiskers grew vertically on the inner pore
walls as well. After two infusion procedures and a final 1000 °C sintering step, the
micro-whisker network was filled with thick layers of BCP nanoparticles, mainly
residing on the root and top of the whiskers.
Fig. 1. The schematic diagram of the fabrication process for the hBCP bioceramic with changing surface topographies throughout the main steps as observed by SEM.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC
CE
PT ED
The XRD pattern in Fig. 2 indicated a phase transition from the initial BCP (HA:
β-TCP = 2:8) to the hBCP ceramics (HA: β-TCP = 5:5). The hydrothermal treatment
induced a transform of the β-TCP phase into the HA phase, whilst the infusion and
final sintering steps brought in new β-TCP content. The net result was an increment of
HA content up to 50% in the final composition of the hBCP ceramic. In order to
exclude the effect of phase composition on biological response, a control BCP
material was traditionally synthesized with a similar composition to the hBCP used in
the current study without any modification on the surface. The phase composition of
the synthesized control BCP was also confirmed in Fig. 2.
Fig. 2. XRD spectra of the hBCP, the control BCP and the initial BCP before the hydrothermal treatment; Standard spectra of β-TCP and HA were provided below.

sections.heading: 3.2. X-ray, Micro-CT rendered images and data of new bone formation
sections.text:
A pilot in vivo X-ray scanning of one individual animal from each group at week 4
was used to assess the healing efficacy (Fig. 3A). The radiolucent lines at both ends of
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
the cylindrical control BCP group indicated a slow integration with the adjacent host
bone. At the end week 12, a gap still existed at the proximal end of the control BCP
implant. As for the hBCP group, the line at the proximal end was blurred at week 4
and the contour of the ends were no longer distinguishable from the host bone at the
end of week 12. The morphology of the implant with bone was reconstructed using
micro-CT (Fig. 3B). In accordance with the X-ray images, the hBCP group showed a
better integration with host bone tissue at the end of week 12. The global greyscale
threshold used in the current study could effectively distinguish the newly formed
bone from the material body (Fig. 3C). The bone substitution for bioceramic
degradation can be observed in both groups. Due to the interconnected porous
structure, the ingrowth of bone was deep into the center of the material. In the control
BCP group, an uneven amount of bony material was found at periphery, which may
be the callus formation. However, in the hBCP group, the bony tissue tightly enfolded
the remaining hBCP material. Quantification of micro-CT analysis revealed that the
bone to material ratio was 9.1% higher in the hBCP group compared to that of the
control BCP group (p < 0.05) (Fig.3D).

3.3. Histological analysis of bone regeneration
M AN

The results of histological analysis for the retrieved samples after 12 weeks of
implantation were presented in Fig. 4. Without staining, the light microscopy images
of longitudinal sections (left side) showed that the inner pores of the hBCP implants
were filled with more reddish tissue than those of the control BCP implant. Results of
non-decalcified specimens stained with TB and H&E (right side) indicated that new
bone was formed, commencing from the periphery of the host bone towards the inner
pores of the hBCP and control BCP groups. Both bioceramic groups demonstrated
good host bone integration and osteoconductive ability. The newly formed bone (pale
blue in TB staining) was closely attached to the wall of inner pores of the bioceramics.
Mineralized front (light purple in TB staining) could be visualized at the edge of the
newly formed bone. Other representative images can be found in Supplementary
figure 1. The histological observation confirmed the existence of the new bone
segmented via micro-CT thresholding. The bone to material ratio of the two groups
quantified by histological analysis was similar to the data rendered by micro-CT (Fig.
4C).

sections.heading: 3.4. Macro- and nanolevel mechanical tests
sections.text:
The result of 12-week implanted bone macro-mechanical test in terms of compressive
maximum load and stiffness are shown in Fig. 5 (A and B). Due to its structural
integrity, the intact control femur had the highest maximum load and stiffness among
all groups (p < 0.01 compared with hBCP and control BCP respectively). Importantly,
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
the maximum load of the 12-week hBCP implant group was significantly higher than
that of the control BCP group (47.6%, p < 0.01). Although the average stiffness of the
hBCP implant group was higher than the control BCP group (57.1%), no statistical
difference was observed between the groups (p > 0.05). Fig. 5 (C-F) shows the results
of nanoindentation tests on the 12-week implanted material body of the hBCP and the
control BCP groups. Correlations of E and H versus indentation depth were studied.
Each data point in Fig. 5C and Fig. 5E represented one actual indentation on the
material. Power-law regression trend lines were plotted individually for each group,
and R2 values were represented in the figure. The trend lines of E versus indentation
depth were separated by groups and correlated with the mean values of E (Fig. 5D).
The highest E value was demonstrated in the control BCP group with an intermediate
value in the hBCP group, and the lowest E was presented in the natural bone (p < 0.01,
respectively). However, the trend lines of H versus indentation depth overlapped and
no statistical difference was found in the mean values of H among the groups (Fig.
5F).

sections.heading: 3.5. Protein adsorption, cell imaging and proliferation on bioceramics
sections.text:
The hBCP group had a significantly higher protein adsorption than the control BCP at
60 and 180 min of incubation, even after normalization to the specific surface area
(Supplementary Fig. 2). CLSM observations of FDA/PI staining were provided in
Supplementary Fig. 3A, which showed that MSCs cultured on the hBCP and the
control BCP bioceramics grew well with few dead cells. The cells were aligned and
evenly distributed on the walls of the macro-pores of the material. The cell numbers
on both groups prominently increased after 7 days of culture. The proliferation was
further quantified by CCK-8 assay at days 1, 3, and 7 (Supplementary Fig. 3B). Good
biocompatibility was demonstrated in both groups. Nevertheless, no significant
difference was observed between the hBCP and the control groups at all time points.

sections.heading: 3.6. Gene expression study and pathway analysis
sections.text:
A total of 27,255 genes were evaluated. The comparison of the hBCP to the control
BCP showed that 594 genes were upregulated and 287 were downregulated. These
regulated genes could be divided according to the fold change in expression and are
shown in Table 1-3 (10-fold change or more, 5- to 10-fold change, and 2- to 5-fold
change, respectively). There were in total 55 genes with expression change between
2- to 5-fold and only the ones might be related to osteogenesis were listed in Table 3.
Thirteen out of 14 genes with fold change ≥5 were all down-regulated and associated
with inflammatory response, i.e., Il1a, Cxcl5, Saa3, Il6, Cxcl1, Il1f6, Cxcl2, etc.

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text:
A number of in vivo and in vitro studies had demonstrated that the implant surface modification with micro/nano hybrid structure could be an effective strategy to achieve a better bone regeneration [17–19,26,28,51]. The fine controllable synthesis is critical. For metals, enhanced cellular activity of MSCs was observed when co-culturing with titania (TiO2) nanotubes and micro-nodulars fabricated via anodization and acid-etching methods [18,19,26,27]. Other studies showed that silicon (Si) pillars across multiple length scales obtained by laser pulse fluence or ion-etching technique would improve cell adhesion and growth [51,52]. Due to the brittleness, these intense technologies being applied in other materials were not suitable for modification of the CaP bioceramics. In our previous work [31], a hydrothermal reaction was initiated first to grow vertical micro-whiskers on the inner pore walls of the BCP bioceramics. During hydrothermal treatment, the β-TCP phase dissolved into calcium and phosphate ions. With the increase of the ion release, oversaturation was reached and these ions were redeposited to form HA micro-whiskers. In the current study, we have taken one step further by incorporating BCP nanoparticles before the final sintering. A micro/nano hybrid-structured bioceramic was thus fabricated (hBCP) with a tuned phase composition. The bone regeneration ability of the novel hBCP material was assessed in a segmental bone defect model of beagle dog in comparison with the traditional smooth surface BCP material. Micro-CT analysis revealed an infiltrated new bone formation pattern in the hBCP group with a significantly higher bone to material ratio than that of the control implant group. There was no observable gap between the hBCP material body and bony tissue, indicating a satisfactory bone substitution rate at the end of 12 weeks of implantation. Histological staining further confirmed that the micro-CT presumed large amount of bony tissue inside of the hBCP macro pores was truly new bone. From TB staining, it could be observed that the proximal end of the hBCP
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
material was structurally bridging towards the host trabecular bone. For a new biomaterial designed as bone substitute, it is crucial to investigate its load-bearing ability after implantation, which was often ignored in previous studies. In the present study, a strong bone integration ability of the hBCP implant was demonstrated in the compressive mechanical test, reflected by a significantly higher fracture load compared to the control BCP implant at week 12. Subsequently, we examined nanolevel mechanical properties of the hBCP implant, the control BCP implant and the host bone. Nanoindentations were positioned in the middle of the hBCP and the control BCP implant body, avoiding probing onto the new bone formed inside of the pores. The power-law regression trend lines of E versus indentation depth were distinguished by groups, with hBCP group lying in between of the control BCP and the natural bone. The averaged E value of the hBCP implant were closer to the host bone and both lower than that of the control implant. Nanoindentation has been applied in recent years to measure the intrinsic mechanical properties of bone implants at high resolution of load and displacement [53–56]. It has been proven to be a useful tool in distinguishing newly formed bone, implant, and matured bone [56– 58]. Generally, the newly formed bone surrounding the implant had significant lower E than the matured bone [59,60]. Furthermore, we found that the implanted calcium phosphate material usually had a much higher E and H than the neighboring trabecular bone, depending on the phase composition and implantation time [59-62]. While the macro fracture test on retrieved implants reflects the overall structural integration, nanoindentation deciphered local integration between implant surface and extracellular matrix [63]. In our previous work using nanoindentation technique on osteoporotic bone with various drug treatments, we discovered that E of the bony matrix reflected its collagen content, whilst H, as well as macro stiffness, were related to the hard mineral and hydroxyapatite content [41,45,46]. Based on histological observations, we speculate that the observed significantly lower E of the hBCP implant, compared to the control BCP
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
implant, may be due to a higher collagen content. We then attempted to shed light on the cellular mechanism underlying the different bone regeneration ability between hBCP and the control BCP implants. In previous in vitro studies investigating the biological response induced by whiskered HA ceramics, attention was focused on the expressions of osteogenesis related genes (i.e., ALP, OCN, RUNX2 etc.) [1,17,29,33,35]. Nevertheless, bone graft integration is not merely related to the osteogenesis of the cells, but a staged complicated process involving host immunoresponse, cell migration, adhesion, ion exchange, key cytokine-receptor interaction, etc. Thus, a gene expression microarray profiling was conducted here to screen out the most relevant biological processes at early stage. Interestingly, we discovered that most of the drastically down-regulated genes were associated with inflammatory response. Tailoring the biomaterial surface structure to control the differentiation of MSCs was widely reported [64-66], whilst the alteration in immunoresponse has not been documented. MSCs have been reported to function as immunomodulators besides their osteogenesis potential [67,68]. For instance, MSCs were shown to reduce inflammation and fibrosis when transferred to a rodent lung injury model [69]. The immunoregulatory capability of MSCs is attributed to the trophic factors they secrete and appears to be most effective when they are present at the early stages of inflammation [69-71]. Our previous studies demonstrated that the scaffold structure could mediate the expression of cell surface marker molecules of the seeded MSCs, such as MHC-1, and MHC-2, which are essential for stimulating immune responses [72,73]. Moreover, recently we discovered that different collagen scaffold composition could elicit varied MSCs immunoregulatory features [74]. The supernatants collected from 3D scaffold groups showed an inhibition on allogeneic lymphocyte activating compared to the 2D culture group. Swartzlander et al. (2015) also reported that under lipopolysaccharide’s immune stimulation, when MSCs were encapsulated in hydrogel, system proinflammatory cytokines like
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
TNF-α and IL-6 were significantly down-regulated at the gene level [67]. In the current study, we speculated that the micro/nano hybrid-structured material can alleviate host inflammatory response via MSCs immunoregulation at early stage of implantation, which led to an advantageous bone regeneration outcome. Other than the changes of inflammatory cytokines, it worth notice that the gene expressions of SLC20a1, ATP2B2, and FGF23 were prominently upregulated. The modulation of SLC20a1 and ATP2B2, known as phosphate and calcium ion transporters, by osteoinductive bioceramics were previously established. FGF23 gene, however, seldom reported in bone substitute material research was observed here to have a more than 3-fold expression change. FGF23 being predominantly produced by osteoblasts and osteocytes is known to regulate bone development and remodelling [75]. It was recently discovered that FGF23 could positively affect the osteogenic differentiation of MSCs via activation of Runx2, OCN and ALP gene expressions and down-regulation of adipogenesis-related genes [76]. As an upstream regulator of osteogenic genes, an elevated FGF23 expression in the hBCP group may have also played an essential role in new bone formation. To promote bone regeneration in a massive defect, recent tissue engineering studies have offered several solutions, including the incorporation of allogenic pre-differentiated MSCs or adipose-derived stem cells in the presence of growth factors onto the polymer scaffolds [77-80]. Lin et al reported an effective way to seed transduced BMP2/VEGF-expressing adipose-derived stem cells on the PLGA scaffold [81]. Twelve weeks of implantation of their construct revealed a successful healing of a 30-mm length bone defect at the mid-femora of minipigs. Comparatively, the surgical use of the hBCP bone graft fabricated in the current study is relatively simple. Satisfactory bone regeneration was achieved without exogenous growth factors or cells except the autologous bone marrow. The hBCP does not contain the elements that the human body does
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
not have. Nevertheless, this study has limitations. First, it would have been interesting to compare the vascularization process of the hBCP with the control BCP bioceramic. The light microscopy images revealed that the inner pores of hBCP implants were filled with more reddish tissues, which might be associated with neovascularization. Second, due to the discrepancies in animal species, genome and proteome, the result of the mouse MSCs-based microarray analysis may not directly explain the advanced bone regeneration ability of the hBCP bioceramics in dog segmental bone repair. Conclusion As discussed, the present study successfully fabricated a micro-whisker and nanoparticles hybrid-structured hBCP bioceramic. Twelve weeks of implantation in a segmental bone defect of beagle dogs demonstrated an enhanced bone regeneration of the hBCP bioceramics. It showed more bone substitution inside of the macro pores and could bear a significantly higher load than the traditional smooth surface control BCP material. Moreover, with respect to the local integration at the nanolevel, the hBCP bioceramics had a much closer elastic modulus to that of the natural host bone adjacent, which may possibly be due to a higher collagen content. Finally, in the gene expression profile microarray analysis, MSCs laden on the hBCP bioceramics drastically downregulated the genes associated with the inflammatory response compared to those cultured on the control BCP, which was seldom reported. TNF signalling was the most involved and down-regulated pathway preferentially by the hBCP material. Overall, our findings suggested that the micro/nano hybrid-structured BCP bioceramics could augment the regeneration of bone at segmental defects, possibly due to a suppressed inflammatory response by MSCs immunoregulation at an early stage of implantation. Although further long-term evaluations are needed, we believe that the hybrid-structured BCP fabricated in this study can be a potential alternative to standard bone grafts for the treatment of massive bone defects.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
